b8833912-e0a6-4849-a746-f4f86a033c34	Alexandrium andersonii	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:246835	1996-08-01	1996-08/1996-09	40.8408333333333	14.25	Gulf of Naples, Campania, Central Tyrrhenian Sea, Italy	ND			HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Montresor, M., Zingone, A. & Sarno, D. 1998. Dinoflagellate cyst production at a coastal Mediterranean site. J. Plankton Res. 20:2291-312.;Penna, A., Fraga, S., Masó, M., Giacobbe, M. G., Bravo, I., Garcés, E., Vila, M., Bertozzini, E., Andreoni, F., Lugliè, A. & Vernesi, C. 2008. Phylogenetic relationships among the Mediterranean Alexandrium (Dinophyceae) species based on sequences of 5.8S gene and Internal Transcript Spacers of the rRNA operon. Eur. J. Phycol. 43:163-78.			The presence of A. andersonii cysts was recorded with sediment traps ( cyst flux <50000 cystsm-2 d-1). A culture (SZN 12) was obtained from the germination of one cyst. Ciminiello et al. (2000) is the first report of toxicity for A. andersonii. Penna et al. (2008) provided the molecular data for the strain SZN011 and SZN012 isolated in August 1996 with GeneBank acc. numbers AJ312440 and AJ30823. There were several sequences in the NGS sample for sediments		Italy	syndrome=PSP
04ad700d-2f7b-4450-a636-53d520378825	Alexandrium andersonii	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:246835	2003-07-01	July 2003	37.94	23.67	Saronikos Gulf, Central Aegean Sea, Greece			From the map	HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Penna, A., Fraga, S., Masó, M., Giacobbe, M. G., Bravo, I., Garcés, E., Vila, M., Bertozzini, E., Andreoni, F., Lugliè, A. & Vernesi, C. 2008. Phylogenetic relationships among the Mediterranean Alexandrium (Dinophyceae) species based on sequences of 5.8S gene and Internal Transcript Spacers of the rRNA operon. Eur. J. Phycol. 43:163-78.			Cyst of this species were observed for the first time. The strain studied here was isolated from single cell or cysts, isolated by S. Fraga and with Genbank accession number AM236854. Non PSP toxins were detected.		Greece	syndrome=PSP
54a0b51f-2252-40af-9edc-c168f98db8e5	Alexandrium balechii	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:109708	1980-08-15	August 1980	40.6683333333333	14.735	Salerno, Gulf of Salerno, Campania Region, Central Tyrrhenian Sea, Italy				HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Montresor, M., Marino, D., Zingone, A. & Dafnis, G. 1990. Three Alexandrium species from coastal Tyrrhenian waters (Mediterranean Sea). In: Granéli, E., Sundstrom, B., Edler, L. & Anderson, D. M. [Eds.] Toxic marine phytoplankton. Elsevier, Amsterdam, pp. 82-87.			A. balechii is not known to be a PSP producer, but fish kills occurred during blooms in the Gulf of Mexico. In the Gulf of Salerno, blooms were concentrated in the first centimeters depth during the day, and there was intense bioluminescence at night		Italy	syndrome=Ichthyotoxic

813595ea-9256-43ee-9b41-e36bab73d56b	Alexandrium minutum	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:109711	2015-05-06	May 2015	37.065	15.28	Dock Cantiere Nautico, Syracuse Bay, Sicily, West Ionian Sea, Italy				HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Dell’Aversano, C., Tartaglione, L., Polito, G., Dean, K., Giacobbe, M., Casabianca, S., Capellacci, S., Penna, A. & Turner, A. D. 2019. First detection of tetrodotoxin and high levels of paralytic shellfish poisoning toxins in shellfish from Sicily (Italy) by three different analytical methods. Chemosphere 215:881-92.			The concentration reported here was the maximum estimated in this area. Alexandrium species were identified by LM, Calcofluor staining and qPCR assays. Molecular qPCR assay was applied too to estimate the sxtA1 gene copy number according to Penna et al. (2015). Toxin analysis was performed by pre-COX HPLC-FLD, UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS, and HPLC-HILIC-HRMS/MS in two different labs respectively. NOTE that here only UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS results are given with a total PSP toxins of 1508 µg STX eq/kg. First report of tetradotoxins (TTXs) analysed by UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS method in sellfish in Sicily.		Italy	syndrome=PSP

8763ea9b-e106-4f26-85c1-0050b9091cdf	Alexandrium minutum	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:109711	2008-10-01	Autumn 2008	42.93	17.51	Mali Stone Bay, South East Adriatic Sea, Croatia			From the text	HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Ujević, I., Roje-Busatto, R., Ninčević-Gladan, Z. & Marasović, I. 2012. First report of Paralytic Shellfish Poisoning (PSP) in mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis) from eastern Adriatic Sea (Croatia). Food Control 25:285-91.			First report of PSP toxin in Croatia. Because of the presence in the Croatian waters of A. minutum (PSP producer) they suggest this species as most probable causative of this PSP event. Toxin analysis by HPLC-FLD method. Toxin concentrations reported here correspond to the maximum levels found in mussels during this period. However, these have to be considered with caution as these were old samples and during MBA test mice survived approximately 22 h. All toxins concentrations were below regulatory levels. Data reported here corresponded to Station MSB2.		Croatia	syndrome=PSP

88722f1c-9b51-472c-823e-e02be582ae14	Alexandrium pacificum	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:833012	2017-04-19	April - May 2017	37.065	15.28	Dock Cantiere Nautico, Syracuse Bay, Sicily, West Ionian Sea, Italy				HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Dell’Aversano, C., Tartaglione, L., Polito, G., Dean, K., Giacobbe, M., Casabianca, S., Capellacci, S., Penna, A. & Turner, A. D. 2019. First detection of tetrodotoxin and high levels of paralytic shellfish poisoning toxins in shellfish from Sicily (Italy) by three different analytical methods. Chemosphere 215:881-92.			The concentration reported here were the maximum estimated in this area. Alexandrium species were identified by LM, Calcofluor staining and qPCR assays. Molecular qPCR assay was applied too to estimate the sxtA1 gene copy number according to Penna et al. (2015). Toxin analysis was performed by pre-COX HPLC-FLD, UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS, and HPLC-HILIC-HRMS/MS in two different labs respectively. NOTE that here only UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS results are given with a total PSP toxins of 4131 µg STX eq/kg. First report of tetradotoxins (TTXs) analysed by UHPLC-HILIC-MS/MS method in sellfish in Sicily.		Italy	syndrome=PSP

Seasonal variability in Dinophysis spp. abundances and diarrhetic shellfish poisoning outbreaks along the eastern Adriatic coast. Bot. Marina 51:449-63.			The concentration reported here corresponds to the annual maximum reached in March, this species was no recorded in April, June and October. Two DSP events were detected in 2005, the first in April and the second September. Toxin analysis performed by mouse bioassay when they were DSP-postive, YTX and OA concentrations were determined by LC-MS/MS.		Croatia	syndrome=DSP

The bloom of this species can be accompanied by a corresponding increase in bacterial population (due to organic matter biodegradation) then there was encystment then subsequent excystment producing a new red tide as the conditions returned normal. The oxigen depletion in the sea is connected with the creation of H2S (by bacterial reduction of sulphates)		Croatia	syndrome=Other toxicity

093b37f5-95ca-40f4-840c-4fa02f540210	Lingulodinium polyedrum	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:233592	1996-06-01	June 1996	43.52	16.36	Kaštela Bay, Middle East Adriatic Sea, Croatia				HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Pavela-Vrančič, M. & Marasović, I. 2004. Paralytic shellfish poisoning (PSP) in the central Adriatic sea. Croat. Chem. Acta 77:627-31.			Toxin analysis performed by mouse bioassay, trace levels for PSP lasted from June to September when PSP values, above the regulatory levels, were observed but no values were reported. A Gyrodinium species were observed in high concentration in August. During this bloom A. minutum co-occurred but in lower concentrations. Concentrations reported here correspond to the maximum of the period. Coordinates given in this article coincided with terrestrial stations, therefore coordinates from the center of Kastela Bay were arbitrarily used.		Croatia	syndrome=Other toxicity

Bull. 155:110825.			Yellow- brownish water discoloration. Two peaks concentrations were recorded during this bloom the first one on 31 July and the second on 23 August. At the end of this severe bloom, a huge amount of viscous foam and mucus in the water column of a basin adjacent to the study area was observed. Mucilage and discoloration could become a big threat to tourism.		Italy	syndrome=Other toxicity

cebb930a-deec-4a55-bb56-367e9806f106	Ostreopsis ovata	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:109524	2009-07-29	July - October 2009	43.61	13.53	Passetto, Marche, North West Adriatic Sea, Italy				HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Accoroni, S., Romagnoli, T., Colombo, F., Pennesi, C., Di Camillo, C. G., Marini, M., Battocchi, C., Ciminiello, P., Dell’Aversano, C. & Iacovo, E. D. 2011. Ostreopsis cf. ovata bloom in the northern Adriatic Sea during summer 2009: ecology, molecular characterization and toxin profile. Mar. Pollut. Bull. 62:2512-19.			Toxin analysis performed by HR- LC–MS, molecular analysis performed as in Penna et al. (2007) and Battocchi et al. (2010). Concentrations reported here corresponded with the seasonal maximum reached on 9 Sept. for cells and on 21st Oct. for toxins. During the bloom symptoms of human suffering were reported, including respiratory distress, rhinitis, fever, conjunctivitis and dermatitis (Martinelli et al., 2009). Moreover deaths of both benthic invertebrates (limpets, sea urchins and mussels) and several macroalgae commonly found in the area were observed.		Italy	syndrome=Ostreopsis and ciguatera

7ff336b3-a83c-48ee-9497-b8abe997a395	Ostreopsis cf. ovata	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:109524	2010-09-22	Mid September - October	45.1	13.62	Rovinj Coast, North East Adriatic Sea, Croatia	1	4		HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Pfannkuchen, M., Godrijan, J., Marić Pfannkuchen, D., Iveša, L., Kružić, P., Ciminiello, P., Dell’Aversano, C., Dello Iacovo, E., Fattorusso, E., Forino, M., Tartaglione, L. & Godrijan, M. 2012. Toxin-producing Ostreopsis cf. ovata are likely to bloom undetected along coastal areas. Environ. Sci. Technol. 46:5574-82.			Cell concentration reported here correspond to the maximum reached on 3rd October in a public beach close to Rovinj. Toxin analysis performed with a HPLC-MS. Toxin concentrations correspond with the same date in which the maximum cell conc. were observed. Maximum toxin concentration were observed on 19th November with a total of 75 picogram per cell. People suffered respiratory symptoms such as coughing and rhinitis after prolonged snorkeling at the sampling site and during the handling of samples from the site. Those symptoms were subsequently also observed by the authors during the initial samplings.		Croatia	syndrome=Ostreopsis and ciguatera

Ostreopsis ovata bloom along the Conero Riviera (northern Adriatic Sea): relationships with environmental conditions and substrata. Harmful Algae 9:233-39.			Area characterised by rocky bottom and shallow depths. The concentration reported here refers to the seasonal maximum reached on 1st October on the rhodophyte Hypnea musciformis. During the bloom period, some episodes of suffering for humans were reported (dyspnea, fever, conjunctivitis, and dermatitis), together with death of benthic invertebrates (echinoderms and molluscs), which has been observed in circumscribed shallow areas. Chem. 408:915-32.;Accoroni, S., Romagnoli, T., Penna, A., Capellacci, S., Ciminiello, P., Dell'Aversano, C., Tartaglione, L., Abboud–Abi Saab, M., Giussani, V., Asnaghi, V., Chiantore, M. & Totti, C. 2016. Ostreopsis fattorussoi sp. nov. (Dinophyceae), a new benthic toxic Ostreopsis species from the East Mediterranean Sea. J. Phycol. 52:1064-84.			This Bay is a heavily impacted area of the southern coastline of Cyprus. Samples were mainly collected from the macroalgae Halopteris scoparia from which 6 strains were analysed (molecularly and toxicologically). The description of this species as O. fattorussoi was published in Accoroni et al. (2016), who used strains obtained in this article. Toxin analysis was performed with LC-HRMS, toxins: OVTX-i, OVTX-j1, OVTX-j2 and OVTX-k (0.06–2.8 picogram per cell) were new for science.		Cyprus	syndrome=Ostreopsis and ciguatera

2fb29359-7910-4995-8bf7-6f27195498d8	Dinophysis rotundatum	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:156505	2005-01-01	January - November 2005	44.19	15.58	Novigrad Bay, North East Adriatic Sea, Croatia			From the map	HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Ninčević Gladan, Ž., Skejic, S., Buzancic, M., Marasović, I., Arapov, J., Ujević, I., Bojanic, N., Grbec, B., Kuspilic, G. & Vidjak, O. 2008. Seasonal variability in Dinophysis spp. abundances and diarrhetic shellfish poisoning outbreaks along the eastern Adriatic coast. Bot. Marina 51:449-63.			The concentration reported here corresponds to the annual maximum reached in April, this species was absent in March, August and September. A DSP event lasted form April to August in 2005. Toxin analysis performed by mouse bioassay when they were DSP-postive, YTX and OA concentrations were determined by LC-MS/MS. The Authors suggested that YTX were linked to L. polyedrum.		Croatia	syndrome=DSP

Seasonal variability in Dinophysis spp. abundances and diarrhetic shellfish poisoning outbreaks along the eastern Adriatic coast. Bot. Marina 51:449-63.			This species was observed with less concentrations in March, June and September. Two DSP events were detected in 2005, the first in April and the second September. cf3138d2-abbc-49b6-a352-6c9b21be5153	Pseudo-nitzschia calliantha	urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:246605	2007-08-21	August - October 2007	45.08	13.56	Istrian Peninsula coastline, North East Adriatic Sea, Croatia			From the map	HumanObservation	present	1 - good	Marić, D., Ljubešić, Z., Godrijan, J., Viličić, D., Ujević, I. & Precali, R. 2011. Blooms of the potentially toxic diatom Pseudo-nitzschia calliantha Lundholm, Moestrup & Hasle in coastal waters of the northern Adriatic Sea (Croatia). Estuar. Coast. Shelf Sci. 92:323-31.			Samples during a Pseudo-n. bloom, the concentration reported here corresponded to the maximum reached along the Istrian coast (P. calliantha was observed in other 5 stations). Toxin analysis was performed by HPLC, positive values were observed in other 4 different stations. During this period positive analysis for the presence of DA were performed in Flexenopecten proteus and Pecten jacobeus. Maximum DA levels were detected Mytillus galloprovincialis on 19th November (1.32 µg/g), one month later than the maximum cell concentration.		Croatia	syndrome=ASP

Morphology, phylogeny, and sexual cycle of Pseudo-nitzschia mannii sp. nov.(Bacillariophyceae): a pseudo-cryptic species within the P. pseudodelicatissima complex. Phycologia 47:487-97.			The identification of the species was done with a clonal culture isolated from the cited data and based on LM, TEM and LSU analysis. Toxin analysis performed by HPLC-MS but no toxins were detected. LSU sequences of two strains, SZN-B26 and SZN-B30, isolated from this data were deposited in Genebank with the accesion numbers AF416752 and AF416755 respectively.		Italy	syndrome=ASP
